comments.commentBody: President Clinton provided his tax returns; Romney hasn't.  That alone is a huge difference whereas Clinton has integrity Romney has none.

How did we lose sight of the real issue - Romney's secret tax returns that he won't release, justified to-date only with vapid, pompous statements from an individual who has a history of twisting words and meanings like Bill Clinton!

Paul Robinson

Your celebratory wisdom concerning our government in Washington under the policies of the Obama administration sounds honorable and pure. If that were the case, Mr. Obama would be looking at a landslide victory in November, propelling him to pursue his vision for the future of America, The American people would be upbeat, praising Obama for what he has done for America...demanding more of the same from Obama.

The reality is...Obama is in trouble.

Your Romney remarks, sounds like a rich guy who wants to be president so he can become more rich...it is what President Obama is telling the American people as he campaigns across the country.

More reality...the American people are not buying it.

My first pass didn't result in much fill, but a deep breath and a fresh look helped settle things down, and eventually finished w/o help. A few unfamiliar answers (TOD, LEINE, EBLA, LLOSA), but I got 'em with the crosses. (I admit to seeing "Anaconda" when it opened, but didn't remember the director's name.) I tried GEARSMITH before pulling out a TOOTH.

I got 3D thanks to DEVO's signature song "JOCKO Homo," roughly translated as "Monkey Man."

Jets organization,owner,hinge head GM,clown/head coach are not looking good.Sparano took a lot of being disrespected by the owner
In Miami but to his credit that team played for him . Tebow is a football player for sure but he was brought here to sell jerseys and so the jets could hype. Woody is a horrible owner,

tm

No one knew who Barack Obama was 4 years ago. Fact is, we still do not know. How will our country look like with 4 more year of Obama?

You say, "we all know the negatives of Obama; we have been habituated to those issues". Are you saying, the American people are condoning the Obama negatives? Are the American people now, to accept the controversial Obama statements and beliefs he now professes to have.

All because we know the negatives of Obama.

With all due respect, our country is in deep trouble, if we all felt like you do.

Professor Reinhardt -- You almost got me there!  For Medicare as a whole, cost overruns are calculated in terms of the total system cost, not in terms of the cost of individual transactions.  Total system cost is the price times the total quantity consumed.  If a price is set artificially low, then the total quantity consumed will be artificially high, which can easily result in a higher total cost and a larger cost overrun for the system as a whole.  So lower prices are not inconsistent with higher system costs.  Furthermore, if service providers are making artificially low profits, or even experiencing losses, on Medicare patients, then they might have to jack up prices on private patients to make up the difference, increasing the price gap.  Am I missing something?

Singularly speaking:

Mare eats oat
Doe eats oat
Little lamb eats ivy
A kiddley divey too, wouldn't you?

Andy:

Thank you for your thoughtful comments.

I didn't ignore the Japanese incident. I didn't know about it.

http://www.amazon.com/Fifty-Shades-Grey-Book-Trilogy/dp/0345803485

Mark McDonald

Dear Mike Zhang:

Thank you for your comments, and my apologies for a tardy reply. I have been away for a few days.

To specifically adddress your inquiries, I did know of Ye Shiwen's accomplishments, and although I have covered eight Olympics and wrote almost exclusively about Olympics sports (including swimming) for more than a decade, I have not been around her personally, either in an interview setting or on the pool deck. She is clearly a remarkable young athlete. And only 16.

I have read and watched interviews with both her Australian coaches --- these came *after* the discussion began to mushroom online --- and the coaches are passionate in their defense of Ms. Ye and her Chinese teammates. Ken Wood, for example, said drug testers were "all over" the Chinese athletes when they were training with him near Brsibane, and the tests were never announced or predictable. (Typically, he said, the Chinese swimmers came into Australia as a group, trained for about 12 weeks and then returned home.)

What I think is sometimes being misconstrued in this fascinating online discussion is that John Leonard, the veteran swim coach who first ignited the issue, suggested that Ms. Ye's sudden spike in performance in the 400IM is what deserves scrutiny because she had swum part of her race as fast as the elite men have ever gone. (That said, I do not pretend to speak for Mr. Leonard, of course, nor do I endorse his views.)

Again, it's not that Ms. Ye won the gold medal, or swam fast, or even set a record. It was the *spike* that caught Mr. Leonard's attention. And let's be frank: Almost any time a feamle athlete performs athletically as well as an *elite* male athlete, well, that is going to spark a discussion. It's notable, it's extraordinary, and it's news.

Now, drugs is just *one* possible explanation for any majestic performance, and perhaps it's the quick, easy, lazy explanation here. It's certainly a rush to judgment.

Alas, all the previous drug cheats --- whether they were Chinese swimmers, Canadian sprinters, American cyclists or Turkish weightlifters ---- have made it that much harder on successive generations of athletes. The damage done to the Tour de France brand, for just one example, is incalcuable, and the taint of drugs now hangs on so many astonishing feats. It just does. I agree that it's not pleasant or fair. But it's real. (It's especially discouraging when young athletes are tarred with that brush.) Even Ms. Ye's own father said after her 400IM that it was "natural to be suspicious" of her astounding feat.

Previous breakout performances --- Michelle Smith, Marion Jones, Ben Johnson, East German swimmers, pro cyclists and athletes in many sports --- have sometimes come through drugs. Some athletes cheat, regardless of nationality, ethnicity, discipline or gender. If they didn't cheat, if they all lived up to the Olympic ideal, there would be no need for drug testing.

Hard training, new techniques, genetic gifts, special psychological preparation --- so many things could have combined to contribute to Ms. Ye's burst. We don't know. The best available laboratory evidence clearly shows that she did not cheat. Her drug tests are clean, as they have been in training and as they were after her London races. For most people, including for many in swimming, that's enough evidence. Some others feel, however, and perhaps Mr. Leonard is among them, that a phenomenal performance spike could perhaps be considered as *anecdotal* evidence. Again, I am not making this argument, and I do not presume to know Mr. Leonard's mind.

Thanks again for your comments, Mike, and I appreciate the many reasonable and thoughtful comments offered in this thread. I hope it continues. I look forward to further exchanges.

Regards,
Mark McDonald

Mr. Douthat is either hearing-impaired or prone to ignoring any factual details that intrude upon his own right-wing fantasies.  The President has never said or even suggested that "we can close the deficit and keep the existing social net by soaking America's millionaires and billionaires."  He has instead proposed slashing benefits and entitlements to an extent unheard of during any prior administration.  At the same time, he is asking for those in the 1% (as well as for those who earn between $200G- $999G) to make sacrifices for the sake of debt reduction. The GOP pretends that the deficit can be brought under control and jobs made available to all and sundry without any new revenues whatsoever.  That's not a mistatement or an exaggeration: it's their agenda, as their fools in Congress (and their candidate for Plutocrat-in-Chief) have so stated.  With respect to "pandering" on issues like gay marriage and immigration reform, I'd submit that the President has come a bit late to the party (whereas his opponent is finding brand new ways to suck up to campaign donors-  like promising to attack other nations for the benefit of a Vegas casino proprietor). As for Willard "taking some chances," he's about as likely to drift towards the middle of the road as a gazelle is inclined to runs towards a leopard.

Well said.  Point made.  But in the end the fact remains that President Obama is the only candidate for the job who has released both his birth certificate and his tax returns.  And the only one whose vital organs can be located without need of a cardiogram and a brain scan.

Hey Freddie who knows this stuf. Here's what I know:

All other industrialized countries have some form of universal government run health care. They get better care as measured by all 16 of the bottom line public health statistics, and they do it at 40% of the cost per person. If our system were as efficient, we would save over $1.5 TRILLION each year, and the deficit would soon vanish.

www.pnhp.org and www.oecd.org especially
http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/46/2/38980580.pdf

@ FreddyB: But "free market" capitalist medicine is what got us into this mess. This isn't an experiment in capitalism. It's how to cover people's health care costs most efficaciously for all involved. Open your mind.
FreddyB, The experiment at reducing the cost and improve efficiency seems essential because market remains no more reliable, let alone free.

Instead of viewing the Massachusetts healthcare law with suspicion, or opposing it for opposition's sake, it would be instructive to treat it as the test pilot case, which if succeeds at making healthcare delivery  more cost effective and efficient, while also ensuring accountability of the healthcare providers, like the hospitals, doctors and insurers, it might well provide the  valuable inputs to improve upon the existing federal affordable care Act, enacted in the face of stiff Republican opposition and after close judicial scrutiny. As such, even conceding the possible hurdles like the paucity of monitoring personnel, or an effective regulatory mechanism, If somehow the Massachusetts healthcare legislative initiative does succeed even partially at cutting spending costs and infusing a sense of accountability among the service providers, the experiment seems worth trying, considering further scope of improvement and expansion.Let the healthcare issue thus come out of the partisan wranglings and confusion.

Any liberal or progressive 'bashing' of millionaires and billionaires has largely occurred in response to ongoing Republican cries for deficit reduction. The Republican playbook would accomplish this through cuts in social services to the poor, as well as reductions in Social Security and Medicare. In riposte, liberals and progressives have called for tax increases on those most able to pay: the wealthy. It's endlessly fascinating how the GOP clamors for budget balance-- until it is suggested that the rich bear a fairer share of the cost.

As for Obama's sounding of more liberal themes: it's still mighty weak tea for many who supported him in 2008. Obama has governed resolutely from the center and much of his economic policy, including his support for TARP and his frequent emphasis on deficit reduction, has favored Wall Street instead of Main Street. While Obama is much preferable to his Repblican challenger, he's hardly FDR or Harry Truman.

As for Obama's use of negative campaigning: that's an understandable response to the way that his record has been challenged by the GOP. His

If you look at Geithner's attitudes towards Wall Street, it would be easy to guess.  Obama needs to be much tougher on both the financial industry and outsourcing, but both his political position and his personal philosophy do not allow him to do this.  One might think that since he is painted as a socialist already, he might as well behave that way and crack down on the sectors that need to be cracked down on.  But he would probably get himself impeached.

I do not recall the Republicans defending the Glass Staegal Act and similar oppressive regulation of the financial sector, or condemning the Dot Com bubble. I do not recall them avoiding derogatory expressions or condemning their use by fellow Republicans, as long as those derogated are Democrats or RINOs.

We have a bit of selective perception or double standard here. We all do such things, sometimes knowingly and sometimes unknowingly. What is interesting about Ross's column or your response is to try and figure out whether the lapses in logic and perception are conscious or unconscious. That the lapses exist is obvious.

The Romney campaign is getting a dose of  their own medicine. Perhaps not birtherism, Muslim bashing suggesting Obama is not a Christian, using a pastor to flog him with as a radical. Romney's only getting to reap the villainy he was so eager to sow by allowing the whackos and tin hatters to hijack the Republican party. Holding back tax returns won't put Humpty Dumpty back together again.

Since it appears Mr. Barrett's dream is to portray William F. Buckley in these pages time and again, I wish he would share his wisdom further.

While there is no forgiving Clinton for Glass Steagal, or the fact that his signature legislation was welfare reform (of all things), please explain the lunacy that Mr. Romney and his seven sons (close enough) never felt the need to serve their country in uniform, but are now promising American lives to back up Israel when they go Dr. Strangelove and attack Iran, a conflict that will quickly turn into WWIII.

And Iran's underground nuclear complex will remain when all is said and done.

Obama is not a great President. But he's Abe Lincoln when contrasted with George W. Bush. And from elective wars to financial recklessness, Romney promises nothing other than Bush 2.0.

Delightful; so slash and burn liberalism is the issue. That is a new one on this quite old quiet person of a time when liberals were polite, well spoken, well read, and sublime writers of uplifting erudite prose, oftentimes offering beautiful mind changing admonitions to do better for all of society so that benefit would accrue to the masses, and those of us who owed the rest of the world a living, would gladly surrender any advantage we had ever worked for and gained in life.

The early comments are rather concerned with your point of view, Mr Douthat, and in fact most have deviated substantially from the civility traditionally associated with classic liberalism, most notably respect for competing points of view and a degree of honorable civility of discourse which the gauche Conservatives had never been known to either be aware of or to practice in their ignorance of modern good behavior in the public square.

In fact the thin skinned liberals are out and about early tonight as they selectively quote what suits their argument, such as the glories of the Clinton Dot Com Bubble, which exploded in 2000/01 causing a hiccup in the market place of remarkable effect, the Clinton decision to rescind the Glass Staegal Act, a disaster well proven since, the use of derogatory expressions, i.e, Republican Troglodytes and describing Governor Romney as a "despicable candidate", and surprisingly, "Obama is not a great candidate". And agreed, Obama is not a great President. Gentlemen !

I think Nichols is wrong, Maureen.

Marilyn was always around on the periphery when I was a kid, but I wasn't allowed to see her films. They were always on the bishops "See and go to hell list."

But I read about her and I listened to her occasionally.

Even as a teenager I knew what made Marilyn so attractive, and it wasn't what made her attractive to 99% of the men around me. What made her attractive was her pain. What made her attractive was being a person in a woman's body; a woman's body that was as far as assessment of her got for a lot of people, including women, certainly my mother and other Catholic women I knew.

But I had enough pain to recognize it in her. Her perfect film was titled for what makes her so beautiful.

She was a misfit. This world, like Vincent Van Gogh. Don McClean has it right. The world just isn't meant for people as beautiful as her. And I'm not talking skin deep, either.
Big bearded guy in the Heaven:  Stay away from her.

That "Forever Marilyn" statue (by Seward Johnson) now stands at a temporary public park in Palm Springs, CA, until June 2013.  It's up for sale by the nonprofit that owns it, The Sculpture Foundation.

I hadn't realized that it's now exactly half a century after her death at 36. She would have been 86 now. Imagine !!

You forgot to mention Elton John's "Candle in the wind..." And her over-the-grate much-larger-than-life-size statue on Michigan Ave., Chicago.
Big bearded guy in the Heaven:  Stay away from her.

My thoughts exactly.

If the very serious people of the Beltway media put as much fainting couch theatrics into denouncing every Republican wild assertion as they have into this one comment by Reid, it would have been a non-stop outrage festival over the past few years. Instead most of them bend over backwards responding with "Well, both sides do it" hedging whenever yet another Republican official claims "Well, I have to believe Obama about his birth certificate... I guess"

Besides, this really isn't the same. As unfounded and yes, pretty unfair as Reid's speculation was, he did call it speculation ("I don't know if that's true") and it's not the wild, far-fetched claim that the birth certificate claims were, I mean it's perfectly plausible that someone would manipulate things so as to pay zero taxes, the question is only whether Romney himself actually did this. The claim about some massive conspiracy by dozens of state officials and many others to falsify birth records, moreover a conspiracy that had to start in the 1960s to get a newborn child elected President many decades later, was always clearly just insane reaching.

So yes, for once "both sides did it", but it's mild by Republican standards. Let it go already.

Reid's comments are damaging to Obama because they surrender the moral high ground.

Until this despicable unfounded accusation from Reid, Democrats could say: "The other side lies all the time, we tell the truth", maybe not with complete justification, but with a lot of plausibility.

Now, they can't. That's what Reid has done.
Small potatoes, negligible, and kind of funny.  It was a well said, worthy remark.  Harry Reid could have said Romney was a Bush supporter.

Senator Reid's speculation was unfair, but at least it was qualified by Reid's caveat that he did not know if the Romney 'no tax' rumor was true, and at least it was the statement of only one Obama surrogate. While I don't defend Reid's comments, they are dwarfed by the endless parade of negative comments and malicious characterizations directed at Obama and his policies. A few examples: the contretemps over the supposedly 'socialist' Affordable Care Act; the canard about the origins of Obama's birth; the cry of 'You lie!' during the State of the

I don't defend Reid's speculation about Romney's taxes, but it's small potatoes alongside the unfounded attacks that have been leveled against Obama.

Doesn't matter what race or nationality.

That performance was impossible. No one has ever even seen that kind of kick at the end of a race (when elite swimmers are usually slowing down).

Additionally, Americans "jealous" of Chinese swimming? China has about a billion more people than the US and the state kicks down more money to train athletes. They should dominate swimming -- and every Olympic sport -- but they don't.

Whilst on the subject of 'exceeding the bounds of civility', or confirming ineptitudes, it is only right and just to observe that electoral history in recent decades in the USA has maintained a fairly regular, entrenched and embedded
proclivity to prostitute truth and persecute personality.
Reid is doing nothing new, astounding or original.
Neither is Romney.

Bryan Barrett:

Mitt Romney has the evidence. They are called TAX RETURNS.

He needs to make Harry Reid out to be a LIAR. (Or make himself out to be a LIAR.) SHOW THE TAX RETURNS. NOW.

The only reason Romney will not show his tax returns is that they contain information that is even worse than the accusation. People aren't asking for his BIRTH CERTIFICATE.

Curious minds want to know.

That a reality based progressive, self described I will add, is civil enough to recognize that what Frank Bruni mentions in his essay in a sober purposeful professional journalistic manner is a scathing critique of the low form of Senator Reids unsubstantiated accusations, is a return to a civil tone of discourse absent recently as we debate the ebb and flow of our political opinions in these columns.

Senator Reid in speaking within the confines of his Senatorial privilege has exceeded the bounds of civility, of which he knows not a whit, yet is clearly within the bounds of parliamentary privilege, for the moment. The delicacy of the moment may yet be lost on him since he is most certainly not the sharpest tack in Nevada, let alone in the Senate of the United States. At this juncture he is on his high horse though the growing disaffection for his point of view, may yet come back to bite him in his personal rear end saddle padding.

Should Senator Reid have real evidence of wrong doing on the part of Governor Romney put up now, immediately, evidence which will without a shadow of a doubt confirm your accusation, or apologize. That the leader of the Senate of the United States would deign to level such charges against a candidate for President of our beloved country, needs to be addressed in a serious manner, and Senator Reid since you take it upon yourself to make the accusation, where is the beef, show me the evidence. Now.

Failing to do so will confirm your ineptitude.

Well, at least the people at Cosmo feel the need to legitimize themselves.

However, the correlation between love marriages and cosmo in India is rather labored. The magazine's circulation in India would be perhaps a 100,000 copies... and if only 1% of Indians are open to love-marriage, that is a multiple of 120 on their circulation.

The prototype Cosmo reading girl in India is from a rich, progressive family... for whom Cosmo does nothing in the way of providing feminist opportunities that she doesn't already have, but does however put pressure to look and behave a certain way, and to have relationships of a certain type. It is not true that a magazine like Cosmo wont be making anyone do the Backdoor Booty if they weren't already going to. These magazines create an impression of what's cool and generate peer pressure for doing whatever the said cool things are.

With all the potential of providing relatively clean energy alternative, meeting fuel demand due to untapped abundant deposits, reducing dependance on polluting hydrocarbons, and also, when considered against the US mastery over the required technology- like seismic imaging, horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracking- the shale gas exploration, instead of viewing as a stand alone alternative, should rather constitute a part of larger energy basket, involving wind, solar, water, and biogas energy. For, less polluting though, the shale natural gas still remains a fossil fuel, with lomg term environmental and physical consequences, like displacement of people, or health hazards for local communities.

To back this up:

All other industrialized countries have some form of universal government run health care. They get better care as measured by all 16 of the bottom line public health statistics, and they do it at 40% of the cost per person. If our system were as efficient, we would save over $1.5 TRILLION each year, and the deficit would soon vanish.

www.pnhp.org and www.oecd.org especially
http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/46/2/38980580.pdf

BTW several of these countries (France, Jaoan, etc.) use fee-for-service.
Five words:  "It's all about the money."

I agree, my son lives and works in France, he marvels at the comprehension, promptness, and humaness of the medical care he recieves, he cannot believe we want to stick with our system of health care.  When I visited him I did not see a failed welfare state, but people that were happier and thinner than most Americans.

Health Care is one of the more obvious areas where the US's fascination with its own "superiority" and "exceptionalism" prevent it from pulling its collective head out of the sand and looking around at ANY and ALL other advanced economies for some useful information about providing more efficient and more universal health care. The US pays the highest percentage of GDP for health care and gets the worst results, according to just about any survey of this subject (see OECD or UN). But its politicians and policy makers absolutely refuse to look around at a host of varied approaches, from private insurer-based (Switzerland) to single-payer (UK, Taiwan) systems.
The GOP, by dogmatic definition, paint these other countries, especially in Europe, as "failed socialist welfare states", and thus, obviously, cannot look to them for inspiration, while Democrats are so fearful of being labeled "socialist" or worse, unpatriotic, that they, too, seem unable to see past their own shadows...
